The average of Amy's, Ben's, and Chris's ages is 6. Four years ago,  Chris was the same age as Amy is now. In four years, Ben's age will be $\frac{3}{5}$ of Amy's age at that time. How many years old is Chris now?
inference:
Let Chris's current age be \(x\).
Four years ago, everyone was 4 years younger.
Four years ago, Chris's age was \(x-4\) and Amy's age was \(x-4-4=x-8\).
It is given that 4 years ago, Chris was the same age as Amy is now, so \(x-4=x-8\), which gives \(x=4\).
In four years, everyone will be 4 years older.
In four years, Chris's age will be \(x+4=8\) and Amy's age will be \(x+4+4=x+8\).
It is given that in four years, Ben's age will be \(\frac{3}{5}\) of Amy's age at that time, so \(Ben's \ age=\frac{3}{5}(x+8)\).
The average of Amy's, Ben's, and Chris's ages is 6, so \(\frac{x+(x+8)+\frac{3}{5}(x+8)}{3}=6\).
Simplifying this equation, we get \(\frac{5x+40}{3}=6\), which gives \(5x+40=18\) and \(5x=-22\), so \(x=\boxed{-4.4}\).
However, Chris's age cannot be negative, so this problem has no solution.
